chapter.title: Transparent Inter-Process Communication (TIPC)
chapter.para: Transparent Inter-Process Communication is a non-IP based network communication protocol specially designed for networks in a cluster environment.

sect1.title: Conceptual Overview
sect1.para: Based on some empirical knowledge about cluster environments, the protocol operations match the following assumptions:

listitem.para: Most messages cross only one direct hop and have a relative short transfer time.
Highly available bandwidth and memory volume
The number of inter-communicating nodes is relatively static and limited at any moment in time.
Security is a less crucial issue in closed clusters than on the Internet.

sect1.para: Conceptually, the TIPC topology need not be the same than the topology of your network. Actually it can be totally different. Usually, a TIPC computer is called a node. A set of related nodes form a cluster, while a set of related clusters form a zone. Typically, the grouping is based on location. For example, a cluster contains all nodes which are in the same rack or in the same room, while a zone contains all clusters in the same building.

Each node in a TIPC network is assigned a unique network address. This TIPC address consists of a zone (Z), cluster (C), and a node identifier (N) in the form <Z.C.N>. Each of these identifiers is an integer value. By default, the maximum values for a zone, cluster, and node identifiers are 3, 1, and 63. Theoretically, it can reach 255 (Z), 4095 (C), and 2047 (N), respectively. Usually, it is definied by the network administrator.

The TIPC network address is not the same as the IP network address. There is only one network address per node in TIPC, even if the node has multiple network interfaces. A node's network interfaces are not assigned network addresses at all.
